We chose our drinks and were waiting to hear the damage. Surprisingly, they were $8 and $10 per drink (which were generous portions). Were were expecting they would be more. I have been known to pay a lot more for a really good bourbon. 

If i lived in this area, this would totally be my go to bar. Super nice bartenders and delicious and well priced drinks. I was tempted by the $7 beer and shot special, but went high class. I can't wait to come back on my next excursion to the TL.
author: Peter V.

description:
Awesome drink specials every day, good selection of music on the jukebox, and super friendly staff/regulars.

Also? They have a pool table.
author: Taylor S.

description:
Well.....now.... I say I don't drink Whiskey any more regularly...but the people at whiskey thieves know that is a lie. 

 I come in here every now and again, when I feel like revisiting my whiskey days for the PBR and Jameson special.  While the special is in itself completely awesome, lets not over look the fact that they also have Pool tables, a rocking jukebox, TV's playing obscure cult classics, and friendly and engaging bartenders. 

 For some reason I always end up sitting next to some truly interesting individuals at this bar as well. Always fun and  always up for conversation.  Last night was no exception I sat next to a Axel Rose and Slash couple in full costume.(it was Halloween after all)  The bartenders threw on November rain and offered up a round on the house for a full on the bar lip sync session.  Never the disappointment my new bar buddies after a bit of encouragement got up there on the bar, pool Que in hand as a stand in guitar and gave it their best shot.  

 This lead to a round of  "Angry Americans"  which is a bourbon cocktail...bourbon, ginger ale, and bitters.... if you never had one.. your surely missing out. Delicious...and well.....its a whiskey bar.. your going to get wasted, so to say its a strong drink would be predictable. 

 Over all  I would say this bar is one of my favorite dives, turned awesome within the last year.  Its never packed, and its always a riot.
author: Charlie B.

description: We only got well whiskey so cam't really comment on that part but the bartender was really nice and we enjoyed the feel. Cash only isn't the greatest but they have an ATM onsite (although it was out of order at the time),
author: Michael W.

description: OK...so a shot of Whiskey and a tall can PBR for $7? I like it. Even though this place was packed on Santacon, we quickly got our drinks. It was definitely a fun crowd, and I would come back even though it's super divey. You can't pass up a deal like that for a cheap buzz.
author: Sonya D.

description:
I live just a few blocks from Whiskey Thieves, and I usually like the bar, but not tonight.  My good friends father was in town for the Thanksgiving Holidays and we thought he might enjoy a drink here, AND I HAVE NEVER HAD A WORSE BAR EXPERIENCE!!!!  

We came in as a group and ordered several drinks, and everything was fine until we (as a group) decided to tip all at once, at the end.  We didn't want to cheat the bartenders and I was keeping a tab since the bar is cash only.... after a few drinks, the female bartender made a nasty comment about how we weren't tipping, and I was really surprised, since I am always a good tipper and have worked in several restaurants/bars in the past... 

then, to make matters worse, during the next round of drinks, the male bartender started charging us extra for drinks, when I asked him why, he replied that "you gotta tip" , needless to say, we were appalled!!  

After all this nastiness, I had had enough, I got our group together and we left.  I saw the male bartender smoking a joint outside (surprise surprise) and confronted him about the rudeness that we endured in  the bar, at which point he cussed at me and I walked away...  

I have really never had such a bad bar experience in San Francisco and I have been all over the town, I honestly would not recommend this place to anyone who doesn't like being treated like an asshole when they are really good people...
author: Ignatious M.

description:
What the hell I haven't written a review here yet? Shiiiit.

I like whiskey. I like drinking. I like making new friends. I like having fun. I like drinking. Oh and I like drinking. 

Thieves always does it for me. Even when I'm a hot mess. 

Jukebox is always on, pool table, surprisingly lots of seating. The guys behind the bar never fuck anything up. Loves it.
author: Amanda S.

description: This place has been a regular for me. The bartenders are nice. Most of the company are good but sometimes not depending on what time of day you go. The prices are great, especially being in San Francisco. I met a lot of good people here. I also feel comfortable.
author: Kody C.

description:
$7 for the whiskey of the day + a PBR can--this dive bar is talking my language!  The bartenders are actually knowledgeable and let you sample whiskey/scotch/bourbon to find what you like.  

Thanks again for explaining the difference in peatiness between Lagavulin and Laphroaig.  Um, thanks also for only charging $10 instead of the $15 like most other places.
author: Manny R.

description: Perfect chill spot, and best bartenders now
author: F E.

description:
Solid whiskey bar. I am not a huge whiskey fan but the selection is massive and the bartender is nice enough to explain things even during a crowded night (and still maintain speed).  Sort of cramped but if you don't mind standing it's a pretty chill place. A pool table in the middle of the bar becomes almost like negative space on a crowded night since you can't really play you just have to avoid sitting on the table :)

7 dollar special for a pbr and whiskey is awesome. When we came as part of tddoc we had found that we had depleted their supply of whatever the whiskey special was. However no worries as the bartender upgraded us to the next best brand of the night. So it sort of became a very awesome deal.
author: Greg G.

description:
PBR for $2!

I've been to Dirty Thieves which is the sister bar to this. Same Concept.

Try their Bourbon and Whiskey. That's what they are known for...
author: Eric A.

description:
I really wanted to love this bar.  But I don't.  Not entirely sure if I even like it but can't really explain exactly why that is! We walked in on a Saturday night after an opening at nearby White Walls Gallery.  A semi-dodgy area, but not unwalkable.  The bar has unusual signage outside, old fashioned and golden looking.  It seemed like a haven from the grit outside.

Walked in and there was ample seating and the pool table was open, which was great!  Grabbed a booth and ordered the bourbon and PBR special (PBR only $1 with the shot.)  Nice deal, and the bourbon was sippable, which was lovely.  Bartender was knowledgeable, as befitting the name of the bar.

We hung out a while, totally random crowd and still weirdly empty on a Saturday.  Jukebox was great though.  All in all, I guess it was an average experience, hence, 3 stars.
author: Jaimie M.

description:
I am not a whiskey fan, due to a bad experience- ***Ahem!
They do have a great selection of beers as well, as a full bar. I love the grungy feel to this bar, I can come here and feel comfortable with whomever. The jukebox plays old school, and it's loud. 
The last time I went, I sat outside while my girl smoked a sig and went back into the dark mysteriousness of the bar. I enjoyed every second of it. 
Will be back soon!
author: Sara P.

description:
$2 PBR! $4 other drinks on tap! :)

Great place to grab drinks with friends and just chill. There are more seats in the back, with a pool table.
author: Carol L.

description:
I love whiskey. I love stealing. I love the Tenderloin. And not because it's cool to love the Tenderloin but because I grew up here and when I was a little girl I could peer down from our house on top of Nob Hill and laugh at the little people. It made me feel better about myself and probably had something to do with the major superiority complex I have now. 

All joking aside, Whiskey Thieves manages to be a cute and cozy spot for weekday happy hours. $3 vodka sodas means I'm going be all kinds of crunk before the sun even goes down. My love of scotch makes Whiskey Thieves a dangerous destination, though. Fortunately, there's tons of good cheap food nearby once the drunky-munchies come on. There are also places to dance nearby once you get your liquid confidence going. Just remember:no else thinks you're as cute as you think you are when you're drunk. 

Nice bartenders and pool tables round out the experience. Highly recommend.
author: Autumn K.

description:
Good watering hole.

Can't beat the one two punch of the whiskey shot and PBR tall boy special at $7.00.  One or two of these was plenty good, but number three almost put me out for the count.  Damn!!!

Anyway, good vibe to this place with a nice backdrop bar (plus Jenne was really nice in serving us up and had a great attitude ... cute too!), pool table in the back, two rail banks is a clever way to make the most of the space, and ... tunes (even some classic Cult from pre-Love).  My kind of bar.

I could see how this place could get a little tight, but the crowd is pretty relaxed.  Getting here from downtown is a snap (e.g. cab, MUNI 2 or 3 line).

Whiskey wise, they have a decent - but not great - selection.  They mix it up between American, Irish, and Scottish.  Naturally, you have the other liquors too.

All in all, we agreed we'd be back.  Not a swank bar and not a dive bar.  Somewhere in the middle.

Recommended.
author: Patrick K.

description:
Okay, how have I not reviewed Whiskey Thieves yet? It's only my *favorite* bar in the city. They have all the good labels that Nihon and Bourbon & Branch have, but without the frou-frou attitude. 

Yes, it's a dive. But you know what you get from a dive that you can't get at the other high-end places? Reasonably priced drinks and generous pours. I love all the bartenders that work there, but Matt is the best. You can make up random adjectives describing the flavor that you're looking for (like mineral-y, or explod-tastic), and dammit, he knows exactly what to recommend every time.

I like going on weeknights because it's less crowded and you actually get to talk to the bartender. Thanks to these guys, I can now call myself a connoisseur of fine whiskey.

Happy hour specials: $3 well drinks, or $1 beers with a pour of whiskey.
author: Amy C.

description: I know a lot of people that love this place, but I wasn't a huge fan. The atmosphere is just weird. Odd lighting, decor, and even the crowd. The whole place looks like it was vandalized, but not really in a cool way. Besides the graffiti in the bathrooms which is awesome. The great thing is the whiskey and I love whiskey. They have an expansive selection of whiskey, bourbon, and scotch. The bartender was really helpful. She had me taste five different scotches for free so I could get a better grasp on what I liked and disliked about each one.
author: Natalie R.

description: Decent dive bar. Good bar tenders. Pool table in the back. Good Tendernob mix of people.
author: Michael B.

description:
Blink and you'll miss this unmarked bar on a seedy block of Geary outside the hotel district. I guess they're famous for their whiskey, pool table, and juke box but we just stuck to beer and huddled in a dark booth in the back corner. It was a lonely Thursday evening and the bartenders seemed seemed sort of lackadaisical but were nice enough to come around to collect our empty glasses every once in a while. The happy hour deals are pretty good ($3/4 for beer and a $7 whiskey shot/beer special). The beer tap is sort of hidden from view so you have to ask what they have (I know they have at least Sierra Nevada and Anchor). Whiskey Thieves is fairly dark and (when the juke box is playing) loud so I wouldn't recommend it for meeting people. But for meeting old friends and jabbering  loudly, it sufficed. 

The most straight-up bar you are likely to encounter in the city.
author: Alexander M.

description:
For some reason I end up in this place every time I go to SF. I think this is because it's not hugely packed, the drinks are reasonably priced and unreasonably strong, and the jukebox is awesome. Also, all my friends are whiskey fiends. Or is that, all my fiends are whiskey friends. It's pretty hard to tell. At any rate I always love it. I think. I can't really remember, ok, sheesh.

Note: this used to be a place that allowed smoking indoors, but no longer. They were ok with my Blu Cig, though.
author: Laural B.

description: Great hip hop.  Entertaining watching people playing pool.  Great dive.
author: Christine B.

description:
I love this bar.  I've loved this bar since some asshole stole my purse here four or five years ago.  

Strange, I know, but the bartenders were so nice to me that night (the place was empty... only four or five patrons and two bartenders). I was sobbing; they gave me free drinks.  Ever since then I've been on a first name basis with a number of the employees.  (And they caught the guy! He was stealing purses from all the tenderloin bars so everyone knew what he looked like. One day he came into WT and tried to use a credit card... his own credit card. Idiot.)

Yet another unforgettable night, I confessed my undying lust for one of the lovely bartenders.  The next day I thought about being very embarrassed, but decided I couldn't bare loosing my favorite bar.  It's a great quality in a bar to be able to pull dumb shit and still be allowed to walk in with your head held high.  They're very nice, even if you act like a fool.

Basically, what I'm saying is the over the years, Whiskey Thieves has made off with more than a little of my dignity, but I know they will never hold that against me.  I love you guys.  I love you so much that I don't even mind when you play metal on the juke box.    

PS: order Buffalo Trace.  Yum.
author: molly p.

description:
My son had been raving about this place and we went there on his 25th Bday with some friends. I was very impressed with their selection and the guy behind the bar was knowledgeable as well. I doubt my son remembers much after walking in the door, but the bar tender and a guy we struck up a conversation with were pouring like the place was gonna be torn down the next day....

Outstanding place to go and hangout....
author: Robert B.

description:
I'm not feeling well...

but, typically, the worse I feel the morning after only counteracts the great time had the night before. Damn that whole "balance of the universe" or "Yin Yang" crap. 

Whiskey Thieves was the first stop after the 5 hours of boozing at our Hotel celebrating a bachelor party. 

Upon entering the dark, drab, dungeoness dive--the fluorescent lights, pool table, state of the art jukebox gave off a vibe of authenticity. Very San Francisco, in my opinion.

The employees were extremely helpful and friendly. 

If I lived in the area, WT would be a regular watering-hole to quench my friday night thirst.
author: Andrew F.

description: This is a dive dive bar that has the seats wreaking of pot.  Nothing special and also not in a great neighborhood.
author: J P.

description:
Whiskey Thieves has a lot of whiskey; Scotch, Bourbon, Irish Whiskey, Canadian Whiskey, you name it, more or less. More than I could count. However they also have 2 friendly bartenders, 1 pool table, 12 or so small tables, around 20 stools, 1 sketchy mens room with 0 mirrors above the sink, and 1 of those obnoxious internet jukeboxes. 

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=N7yAe2MBIpE

yeah.
author: matthew r.

description: pretty fun! i mean duh there's star wars trivial pursuit. also amazing for some whiskey, pool and playing third eye blind until thursday night draws to a close and you're like what happened to my life. but in a good way.
author: Reyana F.

description:
I finally gave this place a try and I have to say, I'm really digging it. The bartenders are sweethearts and the crowd is relatively chill. They have a couple of TVs, a pool table and a juke box. It looks really tiny from the outside, but I say given the location it's decently sized. There is plenty of seating and places to place your drink. They actually use wheel barrels as a table.. which isn't a bad idea. It adds the right touch to this place. 

Their drinks are pretty cheap and they have good selection of whiskey (hence the name). I'm not sure if they have this deal everyday, but you can get a beer and a shot for $7 bucks! If you ask me, that's pretty freaking cheap man. I mean they aren't the best drinks (Blue Ribbon and Jameson) but whatever... for the price it's a steal. One thing I don't get is how can they not carry hennessy?? My friend tried to get a glass of hennessy and coke, but they told her they don't have that. I guess there is a first time for everything. 

Check this place out if you are ever in the area.  OH, and just so y'all know... this place is cash only.  I've seen a couple of people trying to pay with card.
author: Rosa L.

description:
I am trying to drink whiskey (and why would anyone do that), most of the times it does not go as good as I would like to but I am trying.
So why not try it at a place like this....
My only concern is that sometimes the crowd is a bit too preppy tenderloin kids for me and that makes me put on my jacket and move to a more mellow bar or preferably my bed.
author: cecilia k.

description:
I have not been here in awhile, but since moving I've been thinking about starting a support group for WT-expats in Brooklyn.

Was it really the best bar on the planet, or was that just the remnants of one too many whiskey specials from years past? Or, am I secretly a nostalgist? Or, was it also the Best Bar on the Planet(TM)?
author: Geof M.

description:
There are a lot of things in this world that scare the crap out of me. The TL is not one of those things. How could it be? Look at what else is happening; 

Brittney Spears has been allowed to have children, Drew Peterson has found some crazy to marry him again, reality TV accounts for 39% of all new programming, Burger King has produced cologne that smells like flame broiling and I have wasted enough hours on Yelp to have written 800 reviews. 

With all of this going on how could one be afraid of a few crack addicts? In fact, the TL has become much more dignified as time has progressed, for better or worse, depending on whom you talk to. 

Whiskey Thieves is one of those changes I am willing to accept with open arms, despite my adoration of a neighborhood with grit. Why? Because they have a scotch, bourbon and whiskey selection that could make a grown man cry, make a nun strip down naked and run through a brothel singing come and get it, make Burger King execs go on a double date with The Ham-burglar and Grimace... at McDonald's, and pay. 

That is how good the selection is, and it is reasonably priced for what you get. The people working here know their stuff, and they will share that information with you with no attitude. No more smoking inside, which was a major complaint to many. The bar is relatively ass hat free, likely lending to the locale, and they have a pool table and nice lighting. Lighting that might even make Brittney look appealing enough that Drew P would marry her and they could watch reality TV until he whacked her. Except that they are probably afraid of the TL, thus they will never know the joys of the selection at this bar.... which is just fine by me.
author: Drue C.

description: This place has some major grit, so not a place for a fancy night out on the town. But the drinks are very hardcore w/ lots of whiskeys. Would probably not advise a first date here unless you know the girl would like it.
author: Dave L.

description:
We came here because Nihon was closed that night.

The scotch here is cheap. We had a few glasses. For reference: Laphroaig 10 = $7/glass, Talisker 10 = I forget at that point, whatever.

So when we went, it wasn't too busy (Monday night after Thanksgiving) so we sat at the bar, talked about whiskey with the bartender, and just hung out, having a good time. The neighborhood is kinda shitty and the bar is small and pitch-black (a real indie joint), but if you want to have some good, cheap drinks with a few friends, this place is totally legit.
author: Joseph L.

description:
Oh Whiskey Thieves you have stolen my heart!....or did I mean liver...one of those internal organs. 

This cool little dive spot is about 5 blocks from my TL appt and well worth venturing into the dangerous streets of the infamous Tenderloin. (sarcasm off) 

First off: 

1. Cute bartender w/ cool t-shirts. 
2. Free Hot dogs simmered in beer on Wed. 
3. Friendly regulars..like really friendly. This dude was talking about how he just joined the "Bacon of the month club"....mmmm bacon. 
4. Happy hour has about 8 good beers for $3 and all the wells for $3. It runs till 8:00. 
5. I didn't have any of the whiskey, but they had plenty of it. One of these days, I will have to ask for a recommendation on whiskey, as I don't drink it that often. 
6. The pool table.... 

So this is it, huh? Where the real players are separated from the amateurs. Anyone could put down 4 quarters and stay on the table for 8 games at Hemlock Tavern, but not here. If you stay on the table for 4 games at Whiskey Thieves, your pretty much ready for ESPN. I just have 2 words for the table at Whiskey Thieves: shark infested. Thankfully I'm a megaladon amongst these great whites ;)
author: Angelo F.

description:
Whiskey being my favorite liquor of choice I enjoyed this place. With the name they have their whiskey selection is enormous. The bar itself is like any other regular dive bar in the city but with the whiskey selection that makes it extra special. This past weekend was the first time I've ever been and it was never too crowded and plenty of space at the bar to get a drink. I think t his is an Academy of Art hang out so there will be plenty of early 20's crowd here. 

I don't usually hang out in the TL but I would definitely go back to this place.
author: David C.

description: No complaints whatsoever about this place. Came here with a buddy for happy hour on a Friday afternoon and we jumped at the opportunity to order a deal on a shot of whisky and PBR for $7. Can't get a better deal than that. The barrel tables and wall amenities added to the effect of being a dive bar, but I wouldn't call it very hipsters (despite the Yelp description).  This is a good place to start your night in the TL or off of Geary.
author: Anthony R.

description:
I enjoy scotch and like to seek out places that specialize in the libation. That said, Whiskey Thieves has it down. Being that I'm NOT a 50 year old man, I know only a little about scotch, but enough to know what I like. And they had a nice selection that was reasonably priced. 

The bar itself is old. It's in the TL so you get the usual characters you'd expect (i.e. non-marina type folk) but the people were chill. One lady was being really loud and intoxicated which....well it's a whiskey bar. 

This is the kind of place you roll out to when you want a great selection of scotch whiskey. If you want atmosphere, attractive people and girl shots, then check out the spots in SOMA. I'd return again for a drink.
author: Heather O.

description:
Brown liquor makes you do weird things. Pouring brown liquor down your throat like you're checking into jail the next day makes you do even weirder things.

Example: me and Lopez from the 209 are up in here with a big crew one Friday evening, playing pool. In between games I get the  inkling that I'm underdressed -- so i exit and then come back sporting a vest I copped across the street at goodwill. so Lopez one-ups me, goes out and comes back wearing a yellow sport coat and pin stripe pants. the ante is upped. this means we're very well dressed for our altercation later, after some dude doing coke in the bathroom takes umbrage to my "hurry up dude doing coke in the bathroom, i have to pee."
author: Chris R.

description:
Despite the rave reviews, I was skeptical about a whiskey bar in the Tenderloin, especially when I saw the industrial-looking front door. My expectations were pretty low. But then I walked inside...

I was literally stunned by the wall of scotches and whiskeys. There were easily 50 single-malts and that many again of blends. By looking hard, I could see that they do have a full basic bar spread, but this is most definitely a whiskey den.

The bartender, Pablo, was friendly and personable. He kept the lighting and music volume low, which was perfect for meeting up with friends and focusing on the virtues of my drink. When describing their Whiskey Special--a shot of the whiskey of the day plus a pint of PBR for $7--he mentioned that they sometimes feature a Japanese whiskey. When I mentioned that I wasn't aware Japan produced whiskey, he looked at me like I had 3 heads! He then quickly recovered, provided a brief lesson on Japanese whiskey and poured me a sip of Yamazaki 12-yr to taste. It was initially ethereal, then finished strong. The 18-yr was even stronger.

Overall, a cool, laid-back, unpretentious place with solid pours and very reasonable prices. Whiskey Thieves seems like a good place to introduce a friend to scotch.

TRIVIA: Japan is the 2nd largest producer of scotch in the world and has been rapidly gaining international fame and acceptance; in 2008 Japanese distilleries won both Best Single-Malt and Best Blended recognition at the World Whiskey Awards.
author: Bill B.

description: Large selection of whiskey, bourbon. Good drink deals, friendly bartenders. Good music. Will definitely come back.
author: Kathy C.

description:
Petty chill bar in a pretty sketchy neighborhood (sorry all you TL lovers), but have no fear after a few shots of whiskey.

You really can't beat their happy hour deals ($3 pints of beer- but don't expect the good stuff to be in stock- had to ask for three different types before they had it; and $7 shot of whatever is on the specials shelf (generally a poor of whiskey and a bottle of beer- Pabst when we were there).

The space has good areas if you meeting up with a smaller group and a pool table to pass the time (modern wall juke box too if you like to play DJ- Thanks for the DYL playlist Theron!).
author: Tracee E.

description:
I'm actually kind of surprised I haven't reviewed this place sooner.  I've been coming here for years and always have a great time. Some people don't like it because it is always so smoky inside but even though I'm not a smoker this never seems to bother me. I think it's because of their jukebox, pool table, and awesome whiskey list.

It's a laid back place with pretty cheap drinks and the pool table is normally empty or doesn't have that long of a wait. Good spot to go on a first or second date and get cozy while playing pool. The bartenders are nice and knowledgeable and the music is usually good.
author: Jackie G.

description:
Came here for my birthday in March.  I like dives.  No fuss no muss.  I dont have to get all dolled up and i can kick back in a corner and drink without having to worry about some schmuck hitting on me trying to hump my leg.  I dont remember walking out of this place on my birthday, but i do remember good laughs and jameson appearing in front of me each time i pushed an empty glass to the side (or when i tried to hide from other people trying to buy me more shots).  

Fast forward to present day.  Ive been here more than a handful of times.  Its my usual watering hole when in the TL.   Beer, whisky, beer, whisky.....ginger ale at the end of the night?  How did that sneak in there?  I remember someone accidentally stepping on my chucks and me thanking them.  I dont care what anyone says, chucks are meant to be dirty!  Oh, i also made a couple attempts at pool this time around.  Unfortunately, im not a pro.  But i did alright.  

Always a good time when you're thievin it.
author: Juv C.

description:
Ahhh... just my luck! Whiskey thieves you stole my sobriety and now I'm paying for it. 

So just this month, I moved to a moderately shady neighborhood a block away from a whisk(e)y bar! This place rules!! If you're a Scotch lover like myself, a corn grain/cheap whiskey,or an American Bourbon or Rye whiskey lover like myself! This is the spot!! They change their menu monthly, and the tunes are sweet. From early 90's rap that you thought you didn't know the lyrics to, but after a couple of rounds, you do-- to some metal! It's here, this is the spot!!

I was homesick for my favorite whisk(e)y bar in LA (7th/Grand), til I came here and saw the prices. Makers Mark shot for $4.00; that's the same price as Georgia Moon. Tip: Go for the Makers, or treat yourself to something real good. Ask the bartender, he'll recommend something and if you're nice he'll even let you sample it. Yes, free samples!! 

My only complaint is that the scotches are not separated by region. But I guess those types of places usually have stuffy old men reading the Wall Street Journal. Oh well, next time I'll have to bring my Jim Murray book for clarification.
author: Amber G.

description:
Whiskey Thieves...  not charming whatsoever with your aesthetics, but you have wowed me with your worldly ways with Whiskey.  

I have been to this dungeon of a bar several times, and it is sometimes quiet, empty, and has an unattractive audience.  But you get the hot women bartenders going about their whiskey and whether it's actually happening or not you feel like you're in SF hot spot.  (That is of course if you like whiskey).  I mostly enjoyed their selection and knowledge.  If they didn't have what you wanted they were able to suggest a very good substitute to encourage your quest to be a scotch connoisseur.  (that's everyones goal right?)

Also happy hour is pretty awesome at $3 beers and well drinks.

I will see you soon Whiskey Thieves!
author: Jessica G.

description:
A sister bar to Thieves in the Mission, I can't believe last week was my first time in here. It's a little dive of a spot, with an appropriate amount of authentic hipsters interspersed throughout. The bartenders were among the friendliest I've ever encountered; our main guy spent about 5 minutes answering our questions about what types of bourbon and scotch he preferred, and why. 

So yes, if the name doesn't seem obvious, it should. This bar's walls are stocked with the largest selection of whiskey and its variants I've seen in some time. Intimidatingly good times will ensue after a few rounds, and I promise I'll be back to improve my whiskey connoisseurship.
author: Nish N.

description:
Review # 420

I am not so much a fan of the type of smoking they allow here.  You know...the non-cheech and chong kind.  I have very sensitive eyes and they get all teary with very little irritation.  I also don't like the smell that lingers on your clothes when you are around smoking.  Worst of all I hate having to clean out black snots from my nose after being in a place all night with smokers.

That being said, I was easily able to tolerate the smoking at Whiskey Thieves last friday when I came here with *real* friends to meet up with *yelp* friends.  Worlds collided!

It was all good though.  My yelp friends treated my real world friends very well and good times were had by all.  Although this is another one of SF's signature narrow-long bars the area in the back with the sofa along the walls provided some relief.  We parked ourselves back there and the liquor, conversation, and laughing flowed all the way until closing time.  Seriously, they had to kick me out while I was mid-pee in the women's rest room.  But they did it nicely.

If you have smoking friends or you are a smoker yourself then add this to the short list of bars that you can freely indulge in your vice in without having to walk outside and consort with some of SF's finest homeless peeps or tranny hookers.
author: Luis M.

description:
So after I heard this place stopped let people smoke inside, I stopped by last night to take a look. 

I asked for mild scotch under $10. The bartender was really super helpful and friendly and gave us a free taste of 4 different kinds and explain how they are very very nicely with passion. That reminds of me the last time I came here, I had a really great service, too. 

This place is soooo much better now and can not beat the great selection of whiskey and scotch and super great service.
author: Green Mango Y.

description:
I love me some Hot Mens!!  

I tend to treat men like pieces of meat.  I pick them for their physical appeal and then hunt them down and walk away when I'm done with them.

I can even relate to them!  I watch football and even UNDERSTAND it! I don't like shopping and I can chug a pint of beer faster than most guys!!

My one flaw is that I don't drink whiskey.  How can I be hard core if I don't drink whiskey!!  Some brave few have tried to teach me...(thank Steve S.!)  sadly to no avail.   Jack Daniels makes me hurl....fer reals. 

So last week I had one hour to kill before dinner at Saha.  I found parking right in front of Whiskey Thieves and walked in.  

I sat down at the bar and asked for a Manhattan.  

BT: Makers?
Me: Sure, I guess...I'm not a whiskey person. 
BT: You sure you want a Manhattan?
Me: Yes...I need to learn to drink whiskey.
BT: Learn to drink whiskey?!?!  

So he made me a Manhattan and it was pretty damn good. 
(Thanks bartender Cesar!)

He even gave me a whiskey lesson...had me taste some top shelf bourbon and scotch.  

I learned...

Hate Scotch.
Like Bourbon. 

Beware folks....I can now drink whiskey.

Shit is ON!!!
author: Jay H.

description:
To say that this joint is interesting would be an understatement. My friends and I were intrigued by the name (we are scotch enthusiasts) as well as the chalkboard advertising a PBR and shot of whiskey for $7. We didn't go in on the Friday when we walked by and searched some reviews yesterday afternoon and hit it up because we needed to see this place from the inside especially after a lot of good reviews and claims that they had upwards of 300 whiskies

It certainly is a dive bar but I wasn't worried about getting shanked so that's pretty cool. The bartender was rough around the edges (won't get into details about what she said, it was funny but out of bounds for a bartender to say). The whiskey selection is great and I find of like the various levels of shelving. As for the amount of bottles on hand, I need to call shenanigans on that. I would guess there 's maybe 75 or so, unless there's a ton of them hiding somewhere else. The first photo on this site isn't a fair representation of the selection as it looks very organized with multiple bottlings from distillers whereas it seemed like 1 bottle per from what my eyes could see. I picked out an Old Pulteney 21 year old and my buddy got a Laphroaig Cairdeas we paid $14 and $15 respectively. Being from Toronto and the pours we got that's a fair price, especially the Pulteney.

The music/jukebox cranked out some pretty good tunes, my girlfriend and buddy were loving it. I'm kind of indifferent myself. This spot is full of character (the artwork on the walls is a trip) and characters and that's a good thing. Perhaps at the beginning of review I came off a little tight but I'm just calling it like it is. In the grand scheme of things this is a really solid place to go if you like whiskey. If you want to sit, relax and really enjoy a dram then maybe not so much (perhaps during the day). This is one of the better whiskey bars I have been to and with the interesting decor, music, etc it is a nice change. I would definitely recommend.
author: Timothy J.

description:
I'm not changing my stars since I haven't had a chance to go back recently, but wanted to clarify--my *only* complaint is about the actual *physical* *menu*, not the booze itself, and certainly not the pours.  I've had Manhattans smaller than their Whiskey Thieves' pours.

Now that I say that, it makes me sound kinda petty.  So I'm petty!  So there!
author: Martin W.

description:
The bartender taught me the rock-n-roll kick!!!!!!


Oh, but be warned.
The tables are sticky, the bar is sticky, and the bathroom is really gross. However, the 'interesting' sink made up for it. Please check the gallery for the pic! 

Thank you and have a nice day
author: Mona N.

description:
This is a no-nonsense dark, divey spot a couple doors down from the Ha-Ra in the tendernappy...

A good whiskey selection, healthy pours, cool bartenders, a no-attitude vibe, and a pool table in the back.

Only negative is that the place is so smokey, that you feel like you've burned a pack of grits before you've even sat down.

One of the cooler names for a bar...
author: Ryan W.

description:
I really like whiskey (AND bars that are stumbling distance to my house), but that isn't the reason I'm giving this place five stars.

It gets five stars because I started asking one of the bartenders about the different kinds of whiskies available and he gave me some great recommendations.  Followed by sample after sample after sample.

Now at the beginning, I could really pick out the subtleties between the different varieties of Irish whiskey, but at the end I couldn'tve told the difference between Georgia Moonshine Corn Whiskey and a twenty-five dollar a shot of aged scotch.

And that's a good thing!
author: Rocco B.

description:
As a smoker any bar that allows smoking is high up on my list (cough...until I quit...cough...and it better be soon... cough...cough). 

It is a good alternate to other T.L spots and usually not too busy on the weekdays.
author: Teddy d.

description:
Decent place with clean bathrooms.  But what really made this place great for me is the music selection and people :D

Still chasin Carla D's vagenis....

Still riping women's clothes off with my teeth...
author: Aim E.

description:
Eh. So, they have whisky. They have pool tables. But just not enough of something...like they can't decide if they want to be a dark, divey whiskey joint, or a nice neighborhood bar...just not a lot of character either way. 

+1 star for the generous pour of Maker's Mark on the rocks. 
-1 star for my burning eyes & stinky clothes.
author: N B.

description:
We ducked into the Tenderloin spot after spending four hours at the Asian Art Museum. 

They had just opened, but I was impressed by the selection of whiskeys, bourbon, Scotch, and Irish Whiskey. And they had Kronenbourg on tap. I need little else in life.

Amen.
author: Cory G.

description:
I remember my few visits to this bar fondly, smoking like a chimney and numbing my lips with some delicious whiskey.

Once I went and got into a conversation with one of the bartenders about what kinds of whiskey I liked, and he proceeded to pour me six free samples, among which was George T. Stagg, the most delicious whiskey I've tasted.  I think I was completely won over with that.
author: Stephen S.

description: If you like a good wiskey, and are comfortable in dives, go see the best whiskey bar in SF, be for warned DO Not go in there and be asking for some dumb ass multi liquor shot.  If you do and I am in there please sit at the other end of the bar.
author: Robert G.

description:
Now that's the ticket, $8 for a bottle of PBR & a generous shot of whiskey in the T-Loin...7 days a week.

It started out with me sitting at my hetero life partner's place in B-f****ing-E, watching him move stuff from one bedroom to another. I call my lovely roommate Zoe B and the decision is made that we are going to the Tenderloin. 

Oh...the 'loin. A great place for what it is & what it most definitely is not. My favorite little 'hood to be completely anonymous, and enjoy some of the best people watching in the city. Crackheads and trannies and drug dealers, OH MY!

Whiskey Thieves is dark & dingy, and you are allowed to smoke inside. Matter of fact, when I walked in the bartender was smoking. And the cute bouncer-chick was smoking too. And pretty much everyone in the bar was smoking. 

They have a decent selection of Whiskey, both low to high end, and they play good music. When I say "good", keep in mind I was singing along & groovin' to Hall & Oates. The woman is wild wooooooooooooooooooooh! 

If you haven't already been here, check this spot out...you may find the Wizard of the Loin on your way in. Er...wait...that's just a dude wearing a skirt with a tiara on his head. Nevermind.
author: matt m.

description:
Any bar that has whiskey right in the name has got to be good. It's like sending you a clear message that yes you will get totally drunk here.

I was going to give Whiskey Thieves only four stars because I like it, but hardly ever suggest going there, even when in the area. HOWEVER, I must throw the extra star in because the door person let us in after last call so that we could get one last shot. Now that's a commitment to alcoholism. Yay Whiskey Thieves!
author: Rebecca H.

description: Super fun and casual.  A great neighborhood bar.
author: Carrie M.

description:
Its not my scene but some people may like it.

The rundown:
- Smells like feet when you walk in
- Cash only
- When there are more 10 people near the bar, the volume increases exponentially.
- Cheap drinks
- Pool table

That's about it.
author: Claire C.

description:
Good whiskey stock, knowledgeable bartenders.  It's busy and loud though, so go for the bar experience with some icing on the cake, not a calm night of whiskey sipping.

Really awesome selection though.  There's nothin like a wall of whiskey bottles, a friend with a problem and having nowhere to be on a friday night.  Highly recommended.
author: Oliver N.

description:
GEORGIA MOON!
Oh my, you're so tasty.  
I'm fully aware of the fact that this update is written 11 days after my no smoking discovery, HOWEVER, last night, I sampled the beloved Georgia Moon.
You know what I'm talking about.  You know that jar of clear liquid on the top shelf on the North American side?  Yaaa, that one.
When I ordered it, someone overheard me and warned me against it.  She called it "the creeper".  This only fueled my fire.
So I asked the bartender for a whiskey sour with someone of the jarbooze.  He looked at me like I was crazy, got the jar from the shelf, and had me sniff it.  It smelled like death, for reals.
I just realized that this review is basically about Georgia Moon, and not Whiskey Thieves so I'll stop now.  But WT, you're DEFINITELY off my shitlist.  I may not be able to smoke inside anymore, but I've got my sweet, sweet Georgia Moon.
author: Meh M.

description:
Why this place gets 5 stars:

1.  George Dickel No 12 - A tastier Jack Daniels-esque whiskey
2.  Really friendly bartenders and strong pours
3.  Smoking
4.  character, charatcre, character

if you don't like smoke and/or whiskey i suggest you go elsewhere.  i do, so i am there.
author: Steve S.

description:
I'm kind of torn between 3 stars and 4 stars, but I'll go with 3 now because I'm too generous with my 4 stars.

The Good:  I haven't seen that much whiskey since my last trip to BevMo.  Beyond that, the bar has a nice dive vibe.  $3 bottles of High Life when I went, but that might have included a happy hour special.  Friendly bartender and a lively crowd.

The Bad:  Pool is a buck a game on a pretty compact table.  At a bar of this atmosphere, I generally expect cheaper pool.  The location is a drawback, too.

In the end, Whiskey Thieves has a magnetic quality to it.  It's the sort of place that you love despite its flaws, and maybe even more so because of them.  For people nearby, it's definitely worth checking out.
author: Adam W.

description:
Whereas most bars parade a wide variety of liquors on the wall behind the bar itself, Whiskey Thieves doesn't. It honors its name and displays only whiskeys: bourbon, rye, Irish, Scotch, Canadian, you name it. Sure, it sells the usual selection of non-whiskey liquor as well. But this place takes its whiskey seriously...and I respect that. Connoisseurs of the golden water of life, take note.

On the other hand, Whiskey Thieves definitely posts the flag of gentrification in the heart of the Tenderloin. 50 feet away you'll find wheelchair-trapped homeless skeletons begging for change and/or asking if you've seen their prosthetic wooden leg. And you're really going to sit your yuppie butt on a shiny barstool and debate the peatiness of Islay single-malt whisky versus the heavy sweetness of Gentleman Jack? You don't have to shower yourself with liberal guilt...but you don't have to crassly knock back expensive imported liquor in front of the exiled castoffs of society, either. Or maybe you do. Maybe you like to inject hospital blood supplies with AIDS, spit on crippled children, and mock handicapped pets by stealing their little ass-carts. I don't know what you do for your twisted kicks.

If the owners had opened Whiskey Thieves further up moneyed Nob Hill, or at the base of some colossal banking tower in the Financial District, I'd heartily endorse it. But I don't need any more profiteering jokers (excuse me: Thieves) moving in here and raising my neighborhood's rents any more than is already happening. Landlords are fiscal rapists...and you *don't* encourage rapists.

Besides, the owners' other bars kinda suck.
author: John G.

description:
Don't forget free Hot dogs that are simmered in beer on Wednesday.  I mean really who could ask for more.  A mean drink from a hot tender on hump day.
Sure I don't remember much the next day after being here, and perhaps it's not the best idea to come here on a work night.  But you always know you're going to have a good time.
Ceasar is gone and we will miss the smoke.  But Whiskey Thieves is still a goto.  Don't forget to go a few doors done and say Hi to Carl at the HaRa.
author: amanda v.

description:
Awesome bartenders? Sure. 
Kick ass juke box? Got it. 
Pool table mayhem? Indeed. 

What makes a great bar? The crew and the regulars. This place checks on both. Too many great evenings to remember and highly recommends to anyone looking for a great SF experience.
author: Francois D.

description: Such a relief to find this place after being dragged to lame clubs like Swig where all the lame people stand around awkwardly. This place wasn't crowded, had great drink deals and all around prices, and the crowd was diverse, down to earth, funky, cool, and interesting. I had a great time and look forward to going back. Bitchin' music too.
author: Marina M.

description:
oh man, discovering this gem will likely NOT be good for my wallet and liver, but so good for mah SOUL. 

ok, i love whiskey, single malts,good jukeboxes, knowledgeable and non-douchey bartenders and i especially love free tastes. so how could i not love whiskey thieves?

looking forward to becoming a regular here for sure. not only a relaxed vibe(essential for post workday decompression), but it is so fun to learn about different whiskeys and the bartender here was more than happy to provide tastes and recommendations a plenty.
author: LeeAnne T.

description: Great little dive bar in the heart of the TL. I went in on a random Tuesday for a few drinks with a friend. The service was quick and friendly. That's all I need.
author: Christy Z.

description: I came here with a friend and got pretty embarrassing drunk.  Some guy with really bad ranch dressing breath kept trying to take me to a horror movie and bought me drinks.  Cool - keep buying me drinks.  The bartenders were both nice and genuinely handsome, not freakishly handsome, but definitely good looking.  Not ridiculously ridiculously good looking, but definitely cute.  And they kept asking me if I was okay with ranch breath.  Which was sweet of them.  But "cash only" makes me poo poo them one star.  My 90 year old grandma pays with cash, come on.
author: Rachelle P.

description:
1: You can smoke there
2: Internet Jukebox
3: Pool table
4: Chimay on tap
(I'm not a whiskey drinker yet.)
Yep, pretty great place.
author: Thea K.

description:
everybody has to have their neighborhood go to bar. this is mine. -1 star for being cash only and miles away from my bank or walgreens to get cash out. i have never had the pleasure of getting drunk here but i am sure i will soon. 

plus side is that they have a pool table, juke box, and tv's. everything a girl needs in her local dive. they also have drink specials. $7 for shot and a beer. oh a bar after my own heart. there's a lot around this watering hole that make it pretty accessible to everything else you might need including late night dinning options.
author: Ashley H.

description:
It probably doesn't help that I spent the majority of my time after a bad break-up here. That also explains why the bartenders know my name. I used to smoke, that's why I liked it here originally, but now, I go there for the scotch. The selection is unbeatable. With new arrivals every few weeks, you would be hard pressed to find a more varied selection of Irish, American, and Scottish whiskeys in the city. The bartenders (Especially Lori, although she no longer works there, it makes me tear up.)  will guide you into the wide world of whiskey, without a trace of snobbery or pretension.

The art on the walls however, is often unexcusable.
author: Phillip M.

description: Every time I go back, I love it a little more.  Lately the spirits on special have been more diverse, including a good tequila and Rittenhouse Rye and I really appreciate the care the bartenders there put into their craft. The guy behind the stick last time was direct in saying he didn't know a damn thing about making cocktails, but he could (and did) talk all day about whiskeys and poured us free tastes from a few fine bottles, which was enlightening and appreciated.
author: Quinn S.

description:
I heart whiskey. Bourbon, Scotch, Jameson's....love it! 

So I figured, why not try a place that has whiskey in the name...so I went here the other day after work with my boss, and my buddy...It was around 5:30, so the place was pretty empty, and Matt the Bartender (nice name!) was nice enough to give me a few tastes of some whiskeys I'd never even heard of...plus they had Newcastle on tap which always a bonus for me, you know, helps wash down the whiskey and all. Overall, it was a pleasant experience. 

Had that been my only experience here, I would have given it at least 4 stars, because it is a nice little bar...however, the smoking really got to me.  When I went in the afternoon, I noticed the ashtrays out, and a couple of people smoking, hmmmm, I thought, isn't that illegal these days? I'm no anti-smoking Nazi or anything, but I don't smoke and it smells. But I was drinking whiskey, so I didn't really mind...

Fast forward to later that same night...I was meeting a friend who lives in the TL about a block from here...and she mentioned how she had never been here, and based on my pleasurable experience earlier in the day, I said I was all for it...however it was much more packed now, and the smoke was unbearable. Although we stayed for a while anyway to have some whiskey and beers...by the time I got home later everything I was wearing stunk of cigarettes. 
Gross.
author: Matthew S.

description:
The nicest, friendliest bar staff around. And of course the most awesome scotch selection at a bar anywhere I have been to. The prices are reasonable too! You pay $10 for a Lagavulin 16 here, while most places will charge you $15. 

I was here on a Thursday. Crowd picked up around 10pm or so. It was not too loud. Smoking indoors is rather unfortunate, but at I can live with it. Will definitely be back.
author: Mark G.

description:
If you love whiskey you gotta try this place.  The bartenders are awesome and happy to give samples AND explain what you're tasting.  If I entertain anyone who says they like whiskey I always bring them here.  Kinda divey, jukebox and pool table, rickety stools but a great classic neighborhood joint.  And I've never seen it overcrowded so I feel confident when I tell someone how great it is that it will be.  

PS : I hate whiskey, but these guys have served me samples of a few that I didn't feel like puking up - score!
author: Loralyn S.

description:
Whiskey Thieves is probably my favorite bar in the city. When you find yourself in Union Square for some god awful reason, standard procedure is to head to the Gold Dust. 

Unfortunately, every tourist in San Francisco had the same idea, and it's packed as hell there (but still good times- don't get me wrong).

So after a drink or two at the gold dust, you have a descision to make- do you call it a night, or do you continue the awesome at a place that is more conducive to drink and destroy missions?

if you chose the latter, then the only sensible choice is to hump it up a few blocks to the Tenderloin and enter the bastion of drunkenness and liquor that is Whiskey Thieves. 

They have a wall full of various whiskeys from around the world. If you go during a slow time, they'll even hook you up with a tasting. I've never gone to this bar and not had a good time. 

They also allow smoking on a hit or miss basis, which only serves to add to the awesome. I love this bar.

Minus one star for not taking credit cards.
author: Antony M.

description: If the owner is reading this: Keep the PBR + Bushmills special all day, everyday. Thank you.
author: Joey S.

description:
I was here a few days ago and the place was full of  hot guys...I don't know if that's a normal thing or just happend to be so the night I went.  

Naturally, I loved it.

If I were single, I'd hang out here a lot more often :)
author: Karen F.

description:
I think the name says it all really. If you are a connoisseur of the "brown" booze, there is no place like Whiskey Thieves. Yes, it's smoky and gritty - what else would you expect from a bar that specializes in Whiskeys and Bourbons (and all other manner of brown booze)? The bartenders are fun, the crowd is fun, the jukebox rocks (and you gotta love a jukebox that has Rocket From The Crypt on it!), and the prices are really not that damn bad. The selection is expansive and delicious, and the staff can help you choose beverages that fit your personal taste. 

I think after I write this, I might have to go down and grab me a glass o' Rye!
author: Marco M.

description: 7$ for a shot and a 16oz pbr that pretty much sums this place up. 1 juke box and 1 pool table make your night happen.
author: Kate D.

description: Great place with a moderately good selection of whiskey. Knowledgeable bar tender was friendly and gave great advice, and also let me try a couple samples before deciding.
author: Michael M.

description:
Oh for the love of.....

Whiskey, you make me honest in a way that I never should be. It as if someone took off the 10 second delay from my brain to my mouth and I catch myself speaking my thoughts out loud. I share details of my life with friends and strangers in a slurred/ gravily voice as I pound back more. You put a cigarette in my mouth too and I turn into a confessional character from Tartantino movie or something and this bar is the perfect backdrop for it. Whiskey, you and I make an interesting but dangerous couple. We indulge each other in the worst ways possible. That is why I try and stay away. 

Whiskey Thieves, I can always remember walking into you but I've never remembered walking out of you.
author: Veronica G.

description:
If you're a fan of the brown, then this place is a must. Great selection, great knowledgeable bartenders, and great dive atmosphere. There's a pool table with a good match between regulars who were bantering with the barkeep, TV with a good soccer match on, and copious amounts of sitting and standing room. Jukebox had good selection of tunes (we chose some Tom Waits to add to the ambiance).

We got there around 8 after dinner down the street (see my review for Thai House Express). When we got there, my girl friend and I were the only girls and at least 1/2 the age of everyone there. Within 3 hours though, it was filled with a good mix of folks.  Definitely busy, but not so crowded that your precious brown is ever truly in danger of going down your sleeve. We left before it got too crazy so can't vouch for late night crowd, but it was pretty chill.

Had a veeerrrry nice Hirsch Rye (cask strength). Picked one of their Hudsons - also veeeerrry nice. Will be back for more.

Oh, and the ladies room had a nice organic lavendar handsoap. Always a nice bonus.
author: D k.

description: Stop in. Enjoy a great whiskey drink. Ask about the ice machine.
author: Michael H.

description:
When I'm in the tenderloin, I'm always willing to stop by Whiskey Thieves.  Granted I am a fan of the brown, so the pure fact that I can always try a few new scotch or whiskeys makes it very appealing.   

All-in-all though, I think this bar has a good balance, between hip and fun, but not overly pretentious-- and on the other hand, not too divy...which is rare in the loin.
author: Josh M.

description:
This is one of the few places in the City where those of us who sold our life to the highest bidder for a job can sit next to those with poor relationships with their fathers and bond over 4 too many whiskey neats.  It's not a dive bar, but nobody told the crowd at the bar.

Smoking, and often open pool table are worth a few stars, plus they're fond of letting you sample a few before deciding.  Just, for god sakes, don't order it on the rock.  

I often make the mile trek from my house on weeknights to top off a long shitty day (see comment about life sale above)

I'd recomend the Russells... neat.
author: Logan P.

description:
What can i say:

F********g great place to get drunk, and smoke Cigs.
I really enjoy the great selection of whiskeys they have, i mean they have a lot, a lot.

They also have a pool table, that is often taken, but everyone is welcome to play, as long as you put your name on the board.

Great ventilation , clean toilets,, good happy hour, and weeney Wednesdays.
Always friendly service, good people, but it is in a kinda unsafe area, but WTH, its the TL, what do you expect.
author: Daniele V.

description: Beer, a bartender with a cowboy hat, smoke, and a sign out front that you can barely see...you'll like it if that's your cup o' tea.
author: Jennifer A.

description: I spent an awesome night in here in 08.The staff were really friendly and the place has a really nice vibe. In fact i had such a good night and drank so much Bourbon that being shouted and screamed at by a Bum on my way back to the Phoenix at 1:30 didn't wipe the smile off my face (maybe that's why i was gettin shouted at.) Myself and my Wife are going back to S.F. Next year to celebrate my 40th (sob). And a night in Whisky Thieves will be high on the to-do list. And whilst i'm there i'll be looking under the tables for my heart 'cause apparently it's still there : )
author: Lee Z.

description:
This place is awesome!!!  Im a big fan of bourbon.  First thing when i walk in the bartender (pablo?) tells me they have a special.  Bulliet and PBR for $7.  Sold!!!  then i start talking to him about different bourbons and he takes out a few glasses, pours a few different bourbons, and says try these.  Wow.  Such a variety with many that i have never heard of before.  

This is a great place.  Not too dirty and not as scary as it sounds.  I will definitely be back once i recover from my hangover!

Thank you whiskey thieves.  You stole my heart and my sobriety.
author: Terence P.

description:
nice selection of whiskey and cheap! sucks that it's cash only and the atm is ALWAYS broken. and they don't allow dogs, which explains the missing star.

i live above this place though, and there is always a chill crowd. the bartenders are really nice, they have a pool table and good music selection. definitely the best bar in the tl.
author: J R.

description:
I didn't know this many kinds of whiskey and scotch and bourbon existed.  Of course, if you want to sample the good stuff, it can quickly get pricey -- but these aren't $15 bottles of jack daniels...these are $60-$100 bottles of good solid whiskey.  The crowd was pretty light for a friday night, but I prefer that to a packed place.

The one reason I'm docking this place a star -- they allow smoking inside.  Now, I'm all for idiots sucking on their cancer sticks outside...I just don't want to have to breathe it.  I don't want my clothes to smell like it the next day.  And I don't want to sit there and try to smell the more delicate scents of my fine whiskey over the stench of nicotine.
author: Eugene F.

description:
I am a new transplant from the east coast, always on the lookout for some good dive bars.  This one meets my criteria: dirty, grungy, good beer, a great juke box (that's very important), a pool table, and a fine pin ball machine (also very important).  Oh yeah, the art work on the walls is way cool.  If I get drunk enough there, I may walk out with one of those paintings and 2 hundee poorer.

This place is owner-operated, so smoking adds to the fine dive bar atmosphere.  Come here with your friends after hitting up some Scottish Ale at the Edinborough Castle!
author: Tom K.

description:
The people hanging out on the street where WT is located are not the most sightly...  Toothless, clad in rags, smelly.  The very essence of Tenderloin that is part of the experience at WT--- you must fight through a throng of bums before some premium whiskey yo!

Last night was my third time visiting WT.  A casual yet much needed R&R after some last minute bullshit crisis at work...  While driving there, my mouth watered and yearned for the smoky aroma of Scotch, the calming taste of a well aged Irish, and that spicy sweetness of some fine Bourbon.  With smokes allowed indoor.  

Sitting at the bar with mah buddy, smoking, drinking, and watching the sunlight through the door dimming slowly...  I cannot think of a better way to get tipsy.  Besides, 7 or 8 drinks between the 2 of us came to be $38.  What?  You bet your sweet ass I am coming back, again and again.
author: Jiajia C.

description: This place is awesome and dangerous. It's awesome because they have a fantastic selection of whiskey and a great staff to help you pick just the right one. I always like starting out with the whiskey special, which is usually a PBR and a shot of whiskey for $7 (the whiskey is never anything cheaper than Jameson, but sometimes it's a nicer whiskey on special), then I move on to the nicer shots....this is where it gets dangerous...I always go for just one or two drinks, then end up leaving at closing! The bartenders are just so cool and the whiskey is just so good that it's easy to loose track of time. They also have a pool table and amazing murals on the walls from local artist. The vibe varies since they have an Internet jukebox, so it can be either laid back or energetic in there, but I always have a great time there. I've been coming to this bar for almost seven years now, and I can't believe it's taken me this long to write a review. I highly recommend giving this place a try.
author: Melissa A.

description:
You can smoke, and that's reason enough to go. But it's a great bar, because it's just that; a fucking bar. It has a frayed pool table, they make stiff drinks, it's close to The Hemlock, Edinburgh Castle, and the infamous Nite Cap, so there are four worthy bars in about a six block radius. Thieves is certainly one of those dives that is purposefully a dive, unlike say the Nite Cap, which is a real 'what-the-fuck,'- dive, but it does it well like the Elbo Room, The Kilowatt and the Page (well, the Page borders on an unintentional dive, but that's another argument,) But I tend to use Whiskey Thieves as a happy hour starting point.

It's always funny how it seems to be a bar full of people drinking alone. I mean, the place is dark, and that's great, and I kind of love desperation, crying into the beers of drunken hours, and the almost Nelson Algren cast of hard drinking characters that populate this bar.A forlorn girl was chain smoking, drinking whiskey and reading James Joyce in the dark corner yesterday when I was there. That is fucking charming in it's pretentious beauty I have never met anyone here, but have gotten silly sloshed, smoked my Camel lights, drank PBR bottles and had some Jameson shots before I saunter over to the Hemlock to socialize, but for before hand self-help-solo-pep-talks over drinks, Whiskey thieves is m favorite Happy Hour in the TL!!
author: Steve l.

description:
If you meet Jilly B you will very quickly realize how totally awesome she is!   If you are really lucky she will take you to her beloved Whiskey Thieves with her and then you will have an even greater appreication for how awesome she is!

Last night I was dropping a friend off and when we got within the vicinity of WT we couldn't resist the pull.  It was still super fun even without Jilly B's wonderful presence.

Divey bar with cheap strong drinks, non-boring crowd, cool bartenders, nice music,  ventillation that is good enought that you barely notice people are smoking around you     and (I can't forget to mention) cool bathroom sinks!

10/27/05
Whiskey Thieves is starting to be a regular spot for me and I like it more each time!
author: lisa g.

description:
This is a great little dive, Love the darkly lite atmosphere, pool table in the back, smoking in the bar! The regular crowd here is the best, they are laid back and friendly. 

It's also one of the many places you can find the best Zine in SF "The Loin's Mouth". But I may be a little biased on that one :)
author: Ariona E.

description:
Channel your inner bad girl at Whiskey Thieves.  Take a shot from any of the awesome varieties of whiskies behind the bar, play some kick ass tunes on the jukebox, and play erotic photo hunt.  

Confession: when my friends and I are drunk it is hard to pull us away from Erotic Photo Hunt, for those of you who are unfamiliar it is a bar top game that shows you two soft core pics of girls dressed as cheerleaders or other ridic porno settings, then you have to touch the screen and guess the differences.  So basically a fun way to waste your change and time, while laughing about how messed up that one chick's boobs were, or how that one kinda looks like Tyra Banks.

Ok, so back to Whiskey Thieves, it is awesome and you can smoke inside, nuff said.
author: Katie M.

description:
My headache has subsided from last night's candle burning, so now I can write a decent review.

4 whiskey& gingers and I'm on a roll.  And I rolled right down to Toronado to meet up with more friends.....then rolled home in a cab and did some drunk texting.....then rolled out of bed with the taste of kitty litter in my mouth.  

As my Russian friend says (and she loves to make up her own expressions) "I feel like I been hit wiv bags of flour".  

I think it was the extensive music list in the jukebox that kept me goin'.
author: regina k.

description:
Whiskey Thieves. Oh my god. I think I'm in love. How is it that I never visited you before? Why have I neglected you, you beautiful little gem of hip whiskey lover's delicious? Actually, I know exactly why, but this is a Yelp review and, as much as I adore my Yelp friends, the reason I've previously avoided Whiskey Thieves is, in the immortal words of Salt-N-Pepa, none of yo' biznezz. Thankfully, I got over my avoidance issue and took BART to Civic Center the other night, from whence I trudged up to Geary and into the welcoming arms of my new beau, Whiskey Thieves. Ahhhhh. 

Existing on the same block of Geary as the always poppin' and very chill Caffeine and the ever-popular Cairo Nights, Whiskey Thieves offers myriad opportunities. You can get drunk and then order from the Domino's across the street! You can get trashed on whiskey and then smoke yourself sick on flavored tobacco at Cairo. Shit, this is the TL, so you can get drunk, smoke a blunt out front and then spend the rest of the evening barfing into the gutter, if you really want. The establishment is delightfully underlit, with a stainless bar that resonates charmingly when you (are really drunk and) knock on it. You can leave knuckle marks if you're forceful enough, but I'm a lover, not a fighter, so this is not part of my repertoire. Behind the bar, the wall is covered with more bottles of whiskey than I have ever seen in one establishment. On the left side of the bar are Irish and Scotch whiskeys, and the right houses North American whiskeys, including a delightful variety of bourbon (mah whiskey o' choice), from the inexpensive to ridiculously (to my mind) expensive shots that my peasant's palate is not refined enough for.

My friends and I came on Thursday, during happy hour, when you can get a shot of ANY whiskey and receive a can of beer for a dollar. Not bad, eh? My friend ordered a shot of Scotch that was about $8...and a PBR, which may not be the most appropriate accompaniment, but for $1? Fucks yes. Keep em coming, barkeep. I ordered a Jack Daniels Single Barrel and a Tecate. Again, not a bad deal for a buck. There was also a crowd of people indulging in whiskey tasting--this is, perhaps, the free whiskey tasting which I've heard spoken of. But we weren't sure if it was free or not, so we didn't inquire. And potentially missed out. But it's a-okay, because after happy hour ended, a generous shot of Bushmills and a PBR only set you back $5. 

On top of the outrageously good prices and excessive (in a good way) whiskey selection, the bartenders were ceaselessly friendly and helpful--and more than willing to offer up samples, even of the more expensive selections. When I saw a man taking samples of 3 different bourbons, the least expensive of which was either $12 or $15 a shot, I drunkenly told the bartender that she could give me samples too. And you know what? She did--without hesitation.

And this is how I learned that I prefer Makers Mark and Knob Creek to very expensive bottles of bourbon. 

Overall, though I know that I won't be coming here very often (wish I could), Whiskey Thieves is probably the coolest new-to-me bar I've been to in a while. There are benches and cool pleather cubes to sit on, a few low tables, extra seating and a pool table in the back, and really friendly staff AND customers, who were more than willing to shoot the shit, let me bum smokes, borrow their lighters, wear their hats, etc. And they have punk rock on the jukebox. 

Sold. 150% sold.
author: Ashley M.

description: Lots of whisky ...seems like heaven...but very bad first experience...I don't blame anybody but me for not hearing properly over loud jukebox ...without going to too many details - I'll come back and try them again this time with pen and paper to write the drink price so there will be no mistakes.
author: Dupa B.

description: Place is not bad for a cuddy spot in the TL. Cheap beers. I guess PBR oil cans are the choice of juice. Good spot to get shitfaced.
author: Lndn O.

description:
My lungs hurt from the thick cigarette smoke & my hair and clothes are suffering the consequences of the cigarette stench. I think the issue is that smokers flock here because Whiskey Thieves is one of a handful of bars in SF that allow smoking. The artwork on the wall was disturbing & just plain bad. This place was totally divey & once 11pm hit, it was packed wall-to-wall with 20-something hipsters.

Pluses:
- awesome whiskey selection. I ordered the Buffalo Trace whiskey and enjoyed it a lot.
- Good jukebox filled with great music.
author: Kevan M.

description:
Once it opened I went there to escape the crowds of the Hemlock and met a cowboy that I now have as a friend...but that's a long story. I was awaiting my drinking buddy who was trying to get in some girl's pants at the Hemlock so I ordered a beer and told the bartender moneyboy was on the way. He decided we should all do some Jameson shots..so I gladly had one or two of those and ended up making out with the cowboy. Moneyboy struck out, but we all had a great time drinking it up with the bartender and some other friendly folks. Ever since then, every time I go it's a good time. Visit their sister bars Dirty and Thieves Tavern in the Mission!
You can also find the Ha Ra crusties here on occasion.

Way too smokey and all my favorite bar staff are gone, still, I enjoy myself here with a lively dose of debauchery.
author: Colleen B.

description:
I came here once (even though I live right by it) to watch a friend spin.  Needless to say good music, hehe.  

Nothing special to report.  It was comfortable atmosphere I guess.  Nice and dark.  Only thing that kinda annoyed me was when the bartender asked me for my ID when I didn't even order a drink.  I was just standing there, not even at the bar.   (They also had a guy at the door who had already checked my ID.)  Thought that was a little strange.
author: Mary R.

description:
Amazing.

The fantastic bartender took her time finding me, a booze-lover, pretty well schooled spiritualist, but whiskey novice the perfect drink, even though it was a busy saturday night. 

And, the smoky interior and the pool table reminded me of my hometown.
author: Caroline C.

description:
I love whiskey. But I hate smoking inside a bar, especially when it's from a bunch of ugly hipsters with their extremely tight jeans. Thanks, but no thanks. I'll get my whiskey elsewhere!

I will say that the bartender was awesome though and extremely helpful.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
dude i just wrote a great review for this place a minute ago and it got deleted!!!!!!

anyway, the gist of the review was that i love this place.  it's like my home away from home!  the bartenders are all really cool (even if joe lee doesn't work here anymore), and the whiskey selection is one of the best (if not THE best) in the city!

personally, i'm a bourbon girl, but if you're not sure what to order, ask one of the awesome (not to mention HOT) bartenders, and they're sure to give you the low down.

mostly, the place just has a really awesome vibe, and unlike some other places in the neighborhood (*cough* hemlock), it's totally unpretentious.  it doesn't matter what age you are, how you're dressed or where you're from.  as long as you're friendly, everyone's welcome!

p.s.  they're celebrating their 3 year anniversary this week!  congratulations, guys!!!

p.p.s.  smoker friendly!
author: Rachel W.

description: There is just a shitty vibe at this bar that I can't get over. The bartenders are usually pretty snooty or "too busy". Also I got roofied here once, which explains why after two bottles of Pabst I fell over and nearly died.
author: Y K.

description:
I rarely smoke or drink whiskey so this wouldn't be my first choice for a bar to hang out in all night. I do however have a lot of friends who enjoy both and love this bar. By proxy, I  seem to find myself here a lot.

Ideally and usually, I am drunk by the time I get here so it's always good times :) The drinks are cheap and strong and the bartenders really know their shit.
author: Cindy P.

description: I love Whiskey Thieves. Love love love it. Super relaxed atmosphere. Pool table. Great selection of whiskey. Awesome happy hour. Close to the many other wonderful bars in the Tenderloin. Definitely great during the week, and even on Saturday? Yes, even on Saturday. Sometimes you can even find a seat at the bar. I am going to keep coming back to Whiskey Thieves.
author: Jessica S.

description:
Cool spot.  Great drinks at fair prices.  Never too crowded, unlike Hemlock.  Then again the girls at Hemlock as usually more cute.  Whatever.

You can smoke.  If that is cool with you.  You will love it.
author: Thadd L.

description:
I write a Blog about pubs and bars, and this is what I wrote about  Whiskey Thieves: 

The sign above the door said WHISKEY THIEVES and I walked in. It was dark. It was noisy. I liked it the second I walked in. A group of rowdy locals sat at the bar, drinking like it was their last day before setting off on a long journey without alcohol. Most of them availed of the 'Whiskey special' which consisted of a can of PBR and the whiskey of the week for the meagre sum of $ 7,-. I took a seat at the bar and was greeted by a friendly guy with a shaved head and a long beard. He looked like Kerry King from Slayer but then 20 years younger. He introduced himself as Steve and served me a pint with a smile on his face. As I drank my pint, I got talking to a couple of locals, an Asian guy of my age and his 12 years younger girlfriend called Meredith. She worked at the local aquarium and told me about her school, her job and what she did in general. Bartender Steve had by now advised me to try his favorite bourbon, a brew called Rock Hill Bourbon. I took him up on his suggestion and was amazed by the depth of the flavor. I was always convinced that bourbon was cheap knock off whiskey that tasted of vanilla. Perhaps I should add that my general knowledge of bourbon is mainly based on big name, small taste brands like Jim Beam, but still. This was a revelation, a bourbon that was up there with the best of the Scottish single malts and well worth the $7,- I paid for it.  I hung around with the locals, drank bourbon and beer and felt like I had been a regular for years.  After some time, Steve announced that his shift was over, which basically meant that he kept drinking behind the bar, but now didn't have to serve us anymore. 

His place as provider of drink was taken by a pretty girl with dark hair and bright eyes. 

I introduced myself as Lennard. 

She introduced herself as Simone. 

I was stunned by this coincidence. As most of you will know, one of my best friends is called Simone and I met her in a dark and noisy bar, not unlike this one. Now here I was, 11 hours on a plane and about 9000 kilometers from home and the first bar I sit down in for longer than 20 minutes has a bartender named Simone.  I told her about this incredible coincidence and we got talking. We got on great. She even offered me a free toasted sandwich on the house, a Sunday evening treat normally reserved for the regulars. I loved this place and I already liked San Francisco a lot.  By that point, I had already decided that this would be my local for my stay in the city and I would be back a couple of times. One more thing about this great bar that I would like to say is that it was here that I had my first ever can of PBR. For those of you that don't know this beer, it is generally regarded as a beer for highschool kids and students who want to get drunk cheap. Most pubs sell it for $2,- per can and at liquor stores you can usually buy a 12pack for something like $ 7,-. I was given a can by Simone, who could not believe that I had never drank it before. 

This beer, I must say, has NO taste whatsoever. Some beers have little taste, or taste sour, sweet or bitter. This stuff has no taste at all. It literally is like drinking water with alcohol in it. 

After some more drinks, I stumbled back to my hostel, tired of getting up very early, the long flight and the 8 hour time difference. It was around midnight, which meant that back home in Dublin it was 8 in the morning. I walked up to my first floor hotel room and had one of the best nights sleep in a year. I already liked San Francisco and I had hardly been more than 2 streets away from my hotel. I fell asleep wondering what the rest of the city had to offer.
author: Lennard L.

description:
